repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem:

insert-mode ctrl-r input is treated like raw user input, which almost(?) never useful. This means any newlines in the input are affected by autoindent, etc. This is (1) slow and (2) usually breaks the formatting of the input.

### Solution:
- ctrl-r should be treated like a paste, not user-input.
- does not affect `<c-r>=`, so `<c-r>=@x` can still be used to get the old behavior.

Original pr #34477

cc @justinmk

comment_data.body: This also changes cmdline mode Ctrl-R
Why is `|| is_literal_register(regname)` needed here? Doesn't `insert_reg()` already have that?
Yeah, it does. We do want the same behavior for CTRL-R in both modes, right?
There is no such thing as "same behavior in both modes", but I'll take another look later.

By the same behavior, I meant that in both cases CTRL-R adds the register literally.

Originally, the change was from @justinmk he'll probably be better able to tell the intentions.
Yeah, looks like it's already there. I'll remove this change
This text seems to be contradicting itself.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -101,14 +101,15 @@ CTRL-N		Find next keyword (see |i_CTRL-N|).
 CTRL-P		Find previous keyword (see |i_CTRL-P|).
 
 CTRL-R {register}				*i_CTRL-R*
-		Insert the contents of a register.  Between typing CTRL-R and
-		the second character, '"' will be displayed to indicate that
-		you are expected to enter the name of a register.
-		The text is inserted as if you typed it, but mappings and
-		abbreviations are not used.  If you have options like
-		'textwidth', 'formatoptions', or 'autoindent' set, this will
-		influence what will be inserted.  This is different from what
-		happens with the "p" command and pasting with the mouse.
+		Insert the contents of a register. When used with named
+		registers (A-Z,a-z,0-9) text is inserted literaly. Between
+		typing CTRL-R and the second character, '"' will be displayed
+		to indicate that you are expected to enter the name of a
+		register. The text is inserted as if you typed it, but
+		mappings and abbreviations are not used.  If you have options
+		like 'textwidth', 'formatoptions', or 'autoindent' set, this
+		will influence what will be inserted.  This is different from
+		what happens with the "p" command and pasting with the mouse.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    it('inserts named registers literally', function()
```

```suggestion
- |i_CTRL-R| inserts named registers (A-Z,a-z,0-9) literally like paste instead of
```

comment_data.body: You need to update `:h c_CTRL-R` as well.
Updated
what about clipboard register (`<c-r>+`)? that is the main (common) purpose of this change.

 		register.
-		The text is inserted as if you typed it, but mappings and
-		abbreviations are not used.  Command-line completion through
-		'wildchar' is not triggered though.  And characters that end
-		the command line are inserted literally (<Esc>, <CR>, <NL>,
-		<C-C>).  A <BS> or CTRL-W could still end the command line
-		though, and remaining characters will then be interpreted in
-		another mode, which might not be what you intended.
+		When used with named registers (A-Z,a-z,0-9) text is inserted
+		literally like pasting with "p". For other registers, the text
+		is inserted as if you typed it, but mappings and abbreviations

comment_data.body: This is applied on A-Za-z0-9+* registers

just call it `star` :) 

or leave the star out, "+" is clear enough. who cares about `*` 👀 

```suggestion
		When used with named or clipboard registers (A-Z,a-z,0-9,+,star)
```

comment_regular_data.body: Nice, LGTM after the docs CI is fixed

> Nice, LGTM after the docs CI is fixed

How do I escape * in vimdoc, actually? It's treating the * as vimdoc syntax.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

title: feat(editor)!: insert-mode ctrl-r should work like paste
